Fig. 1 Trends in use of platinum group metals in cars globally. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 Vehicle evaluation catalyst configuration. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 Conversion efficiency of Pd-only (Catalyst-A), Pd/Rh (Catalyst-B) and Rh-only catalyst (Catalyst-C) for CO, HC and NOx at different λ, (a)-(c): fresh catalyst, (d)-(f): aged catalyst. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 H2-TPR profile of Pd-only (Catalyst-A), Pd/Rh (Catalyst-B) and Rh-only catalyst (Catalyst-C), all catalysts are aged at 1000 °C for 4 h in oven. Fig. 5 Fig. 6 WLTC modal CO (a), THC (b) and NOx (c) emissions of aged Catalyst B(Pd/Rh)and Catalyst C (Rh-only). Fig. 6 Fig. 7 Vehicle emission test results for Pd/Rh and Rh-only system. Fig. 8 Fig. 9 NOx conversion and corresponding yield of N2O curves on Catalyst A (Pd-only), catalyst B (Pd/Rh) and Catalyst C (Rh only), (a): fresh, (b):1000 °C/10 h ageing. A comparative study of Rh-only, Pd-only and Pd/Rh catalysts Tingting Zheng Conceptualization Methodology Investigation Data curation Writing - original draft a b Bing Lu Experiment Data curation Investigation b Gavin Harle Methodology Writing - review & editing b Dongxia Yang Resources Supervision a b Chengxiong Wang Methodology a b Yunkun Zhao Supervision a b * a State Key Laboratory of Advanced Technologies for Comprehensive Utilization of Platinum Metals, Kunming Institute of Precious Metals, Kunming 650106, China State Key Laboratory of Advanced Technologies for Comprehensive Utilization of Platinum Metals Kunming Institute of Precious Metals Kunming 650106 China State Key Laboratory of Advanced Technologies for Comprehensive Utilization of Platinum Metals, Kunming Institute of Precious Metals, Kunming 650106, China b State-Local Joint Engineering Laboratory of Precious Metal Catalytic Technology and Application, Kunming Sino-platinum Metals Catalysts Co. Ltd., Kunming 650106, China ⁎ Corresponding author at: State Key Laboratory of Advanced Technologies for Comprehensive Utilization of Platinum Metals, Kunming Institute of Precious Metals, Kunming 650106, China. State Key Laboratory of Advanced Technologies for Comprehensive Utilization of Platinum Metals Kunming Institute of Precious Metals Kunming 650106 China Graphical abstract With the increase in worldwide automobile usage and the tightening of associated emissions legislation, the total demand of PGMs for use in automotive emission control catalysts is growing. Reducing the amount of required PGM in automotive catalysts as well as maintaining or improving the associated catalytic performance is an area of significant focus. This work presents a comparative study of the catalytic activity of Pd-only, Pd/Rh and Rh-only catalyst systems with respect to CO, HC and NOx conversion. The Rh-only catalyst has been shown to have the potential to improve CO and NOx conversions when functioning as a downstream catalyst compared with a Pd/Rh catalyst as well as reducing the usage of precious metals. In addition the formation of the three way catalysis by-products N2O and NH3 in different catalyst systems was investigated. The temperature of N2O and NH3 formation was shown to correlate with NOx light off temperatures and to vary depending upon the catalyst system employed and ageing conditions. The Rh-only catalyst was shown to generate the highest amount of N2O and the Pd-only catalyst the highest amount of NH3. Keywords Rh-only three way catalyst Downstream catalyst N2O and NH3 formation Reducing the usage of precious metals 1 Introduction It has been over 45 years since the introduction of the first catalytic converter to reduce emissions from the internal combustion engine. Three-way catalysts (TWCs) have subsequently been widely applied on stoichiometric gasoline engine powered vehicles to reduce tailpipe emissions of hydrocarbons (HC), carbon monoxide (CO) and nitrogen oxides (NOx). Precious group metals (PGMs) such as Pt, Pd, and Rh are employed in TWCs as the active catalytic species. Pt and Pd are utilized for removal of CO and HC whilst Rh is the main component for NOx control. Among these PGMs Rh is the scarcest [1], with no alternative material available. With the increase in worldwide automobile usage [2] and the tightening of associated emissions legislation, the total demand of PGMs for use in automotive emission control catalysts is growing. Fig. 1 shows the trend in PGM utilization within the automobile industry over recent years [2]. Due to the rarity and associated cost of PGMs, reducing the amount of PGM required in automotive catalysts is an area of significant focus. Pd-Rh catalysts are the current mainstream of the exhaust after treatment system. In order to reduce the amount of precious metal required for functionality in three-way catalysts, various studies have been carried out with a view to enhancing the catalytic function of PGMs, including utilizing the mutual interaction between precious metals and carriers [3,4], the application of new materials [5,6], new preparation processes [7], and optimization of the catalyst structure [3,8]. Owing in part to a number of these methodologies, the performance of catalyst systems has improved and the amount of required PGM reduced. However the demand for reduced usage of PGMs in TWCs is still high within the industry. Typical TWC catalyst configurations consist of single brick or multi-brick systems in the exhaust line of the vehicle. If more than one catalyst is in use, the catalysts can be adjoined together in a single convertor or separated by a defined distance in separate convertors. A common configuration for large and cooler engines which start working at relatively low temperature is to have one converter in a close coupled (CC) position, with the second converter in an under floor (UF) location. In such configurations close coupled catalysts (CCC) require high conversions of CO, THC and NOx as well as excellent high temperature stability owing to the high operating temperatures. It therefore proves necessary to utilize high levels of Pd or Pt and Rh within the catalyst. However underfloor catalysts (UFC) are less demanding in terms of PGM levels, usually containing lower PGM loadings, and sometimes consisting of a single PGM such as Pd or Rh. During three way catalysis undesired N2O and NH3 by-products are formed [9–12]. NH3 represents a secondary pollutant that is formed in the TWC process during NO conversion under rich operating conditions. NH3 acts as a precursor to form secondary atmospheric aerosols, and its reaction with nitrogen and ammonium nitrate forms particulate matter, which poses a severe threat to health [13]. N2O is rated as a strong greenhouse gas with a greenhouse potential of 300-times greater than that of CO2 meaning that N2O has a significant impact on ozone depletion [11]. N2O emissions from light duty gasoline vehicles are currently regulated in the US and China, with N2O emissions limits of 16 mg/km and 20 mg/km respectively. In addition the latest Euro VI regulations for compressed natural gas (CNG) vehicles set an NH3 emissions limit of 10 ppm. It is therefore clear that the environmental impact of NH3 and N2O emissions from gasoline vehicles equipped with TWC sand their regulation is of significant importance. With a view to reducing the amount of required precious metals whilst maintaining or improving aftertreatment system performance, the catalytic function of Pd-only, Pd/Rh and Rh-only catalyst systems have been investigated. The results obtained from synthetic gas bench testing and vehicle evaluation show that Rh-only catalysts demonstrate an improved performance in terms of CO and NOx conversion as a downstream catalyst when compared with Pd/Rh catalysts. In addition the formation of N2O and NH3 by-products over the different catalysts was examined. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation Catalyst samples were prepared using Al2O3 and CeZr composite oxides, which were slurried in H2O followed by the addition of specified quantities of PGM. Finished catalysts were prepared by depositing the prepared catalyst slurries onto pre-formed monolithic substrates of 750 cells per square inch (cpsi) and a wall thickness of 2.5 millinch. The substrates had a diameter of 11.84 cm and length of 6.9 cm. The coated catalyst substrates were then calcined at 500 °C for 1 h using muffle furnace to obtain a final target washcoat loading of 200 g/L. The PGM content for each catalyst is summarized in the table below (Table1 ): 2.2 Catalyst ageing The catalysts were hydrothermally aged at 1000 °C for 10 h using a muffle furnace in an atmosphere of 10% H2O and 2% O2 (99.9% purity) with N2 balance. The heating rate was 10 °C/min. Water vapor was produced by a gasifier and carried into furnace by N2. Gas flow was controlled by a mass flowmeter with a total flow rate of 300 L/h. 2.3 Method of evaluation of light off, A/F sweep and OSC Catalyst light off, A/F sweep performance and oxygen storage capacity were evaluated using a synthetic gas reactor system manufactured by HORIBA with the gas compositions shown in Table 2 . Downstream analysis was conducted using a motor exhaust gas analyzer system consisting of an oxygen and hydrocarbon analyzer (MEXA-7100H) and a fourier transform infrared spectrum multi-component gas analyzer (MEXA-6000FT) both manufactured by HORIBA. Core samples of diameter 25.4 mm and length 69 mm were taken from each catalyst sample and used for testing. Prior to all catalytic performance measurements, the catalysts were pretreated under the light-off test atmosphere at 500 °C for 10 min and then cooled to 100 °C. All testing was conducted using a rate of temperature increase of 30 °C/min and a gas hourly space velocity of 60000h−1. Catalyst light off performance was evaluated by heating the catalyst sample from 100 to 500 °C and A/F sweep was tested at 500 °C. Dynamic OSC was measured at 500 °C with a periodic switch between lean and rich gas conditions of 50 s. The principle of the OSC test methodology used in this study is similar to dynamic CO-O 2 cycle measurements reported in the literature [14]. In comparison to the total (static) oxygen storage capacity, dynamic oxygen mobility or oxygen diffusivity relates more closely with efficient oxygen storage capacity and oxygen storage/release rate, or in practical terms the amount of oxygen that can actually be stored and released during the transient periods involved in the catalytic process. Weng et al. [14] have compared the difference between static and dynamic OSC measurements and found that the value of dynamic OSC is significantly lower than that of static OSC. 2.4 Method of H2-TPR Temperature programmed reduction (TPR) of the samples was carried out using a CHEMBET 3000 analyzer with thermal conductivity detector (TCD) manufactured by Quantachrome. 0.1 g samples were evaluated from RT to 800 °C (ramp rate of 10 °C/min) in a 10.3% H2/Ar gas stream with total flow rate of 75 mL/min to determine the reduction properties of the catalyst samples. 2.5 Vehicle evaluation Vehicle evaluation of the catalyst samples was carried out using the WLTC drive cycle in accordance with China6b regulations on a 1.5 L vehicle with a current China 6 calibration. Fig. 2 shows the catalyst configuration utilized. The configuration consisted of two catalysts one in a close-coupled (CCC) position, and the other in an underfloor (UFC) position. For the purposes of this investigation the CCC sample was kept the same and the UFC changed. Full details of the catalyst sample compositions utilized for vehicle evaluation work are provided in Table 3 . Downstream analysis of the catalyst systems was conducted using an exhaust gas analyzer (AMA i60 AVL) 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst performance The catalytic performance of Pd-only, Pd/Rh and Rh-only catalyst samples was investigated with respect to their reaction temperature for the conversion of carbon monoxide (CO), hydrocarbons (HC) and nitrogen oxides (NOx). The light-off temperatures (T50) for the catalyst samples are shown in Table 4 . The Rh-only catalyst showed lower light-off temperatures for CO and NOx as compared to the Pd-only and Pd/Rh catalyst samples when tested fresh and after ageing. However the Pd/Rh catalyst showed a lower light-off for THC compared with the Pd-only and Rh-only catalyst samples. This was especially the case after ageing of the catalyst samples. The oxygen storage capacity (OSC) of the three catalyst samples are listed in Table 4. The OSC of the catalyst samples was found to decrease in the order of Pd/Rh catalyst > Rh catalyst > Pd catalyst for fresh samples. However after ageing the Rh catalyst was observed to maintain a higher OSC than its Pd/Rh counterpart. These results suggest that Rh plays a more significant role in OSC improvement and stability as compared to Pd. This observation is in agreement with a study carried out by Koji Yamada and co-workers [15] whom evaluated the effect of different precious metals on the OSC of a CeZrY oxide material. Their results indicated that, dependent upon the Ce content of the CeZrY material, Rh can be advantageous compared to Pd in terms of OSC stability after ageing. The conversion efficiencies for CO, THC and NOx at different temperatures for fresh and aged catalyst samples are shown in Fig. 3 . The Rh-only catalyst sample demonstrates a rapid light-off for CO and reaches 100% conversion at temperatures of approximately 260 °C and 340 °C for fresh and aged catalyst samples respectively. At 260 °C, the CO conversion of the fresh Pd/Rh catalyst sample has also reached 100% conversion. However for the fresh Pd-only catalyst sample complete conversion is only achieved at a higher temperature (approximately 30 °C higher). In comparison, after ageing, the Pd-only and Pd/Rh catalyst samples show a slower CO light-off without reaching 100% conversion up to a temperature of 450 °C as compared to the Rh-only catalyst sample. However for THC the Rh-only catalyst sample showed a slower light-off than Pd/Rh and Pd catalyst samples with T50 values increasing in the order of Pd/Rh < Pd < Rh for both fresh and aged samples. Of particular interest is that the Rh-only catalyst sample shows a better THC conversion efficiency than the Pd-only catalyst below 275 °C for fresh and below 350 °C after ageing. Meanwhile, the Rh-only catalyst also shows the best conversion efficiency for NOx at temperatures of below 275 °C and 350 °C for fresh and aged catalyst samples respectively, albeit with a slow gradient increase in conversion. Within the temperature range of 275−350 °C, the Rh-only catalyst shows the same trend for the conversion of THC and NOx indicating that the high conversion efficiency of THC and NOx for the Rh-only catalyst sample at low temperatures can be attributed to the reaction of C3H6 with NO and the promotion of this reaction by Rh at low temperatures compared to Pd. It should however be emphasized that CO + NO is also the main reaction for the Rh-only catalyst at low temperatures given that the Rh-only catalyst has a very low light-off temperature for CO. At temperatures of above 275 °C, the activity of the fresh Pd-only catalyst for THC and NOx conversion is higher than the fresh Rh-only catalyst with the same trend observed for aged catalyst samples but at a higher temperature of approximately 350 °C. This may indicate that the Pd-only catalyst system is more beneficial towards the reaction of NO and C3H6 at higher temperature. Another potential reason is the contribution of water-gas shift (WGS) and stream reforming (SR) reactions that occur at higher temperatures, with the generated H2 reacting with NO. Some research groups have shown that the activity of Pd towards water-gas reactions is greater than that of Rh [16]. The behavior of Pd/Rh catalyst in terms of HC and NOx conversion can be explained in terms of contributions from the individual metals. Fig.4 show the results for the A/F sweep testing of the catalyst samples. It can be observed that under rich conditions the fresh Rh-only catalyst sample shows almost the same conversions for CO and NOx as the Pd/Rh catalyst sample. Given the known performance of Rh for NO reduction [15,17], it is not difficult to explain the strong performance of Rh-only catalyst and Pd/Rh catalyst for CO and NO conversion under rich conditions according to the reactions of CO + NO and C3H6+NO. In comparison, the Pd-only catalyst sample showed good C3H6 performance, but worse CO and NO conversion under rich conditions. Owing to the fact that Pd catalysts are relatively inactive towards NOx reduction it is of no surprise that the Pd-only catalyst sample shows worse NOx conversions than the other samples in these tests. The conversion for THC is worse for the Rh-only catalyst sample owing to its poorer oxidation performance as compared to Pd. Within a lambda range of 0.98 to 0.99 the THC conversion of the Pd-only catalyst sample can reach levels of greater than 95%, but for the Rh-only catalyst only reaches a maximum of 88%. This demonstrates that the presence of Pd is essential for the oxidation of hydrocarbon within a three-way catalyst. All the catalyst samples are observed to begin to lose activity for converting NOx once the exhaust gas becomes net oxidizing. It is well known that adsorption of O2 and NO on noble metal sites is a competitive process [18]. At high temperatures, the adsorption of O2 is preferred due to its rapid dissociation upon adsorption whereas the rate of NO desorption from the catalyst surface is considerable. Furthermore, as the dissociative adsorption of NO is preferred over reduced PGM sites, the oxide formation suppresses the reduction of NO [19,20]. Upon ageing the THC and NOx conversions for the catalyst samples follow a similar trend. However the Rh-only catalyst demonstrates a significantly better CO conversion than the Pd/Rh and Pd-only catalyst samples under rich conditions. Fig. 5 show the H2-TPR profile of all aged catalyst samples. Three major reduction peaks can be observed in the Pd only and Pd/Rh aged catalyst samples; the negative peak at approximately 100 °C is generally attributed to the decomposition of palladium hydride [21], the peak at 193 °C can be attributed to the reduction of unstable surface and subsurface PdO or Rh2O3 and the high-temperature peak (over 200 °C) can be assigned to the decomposition of stable PdO or Rh2O3 species due to the interaction of PdO or Rh2O3 and support. In comparison, there are also three major reduction peaks observed in the Rh-only catalyst and no negative peaks. The peak temperature is higher than Pd-only and Pd/Rh catalysts. The lower temperature reduction peak of the Rh-only catalyst was attributed to the reduction of three dimensional Rh2O3 crystallites that have little interaction with support material and the two higher temperature peaks to the reduction of two dimensional Rh2O3 that interacts with support material [22]. The reduction temperature can be correlated with the catalytic activity. 3.2 Vehicle evaluation of TWC systems with Pd/Rh and Rh-only UFC Prior to vehicle evaluation, the TWC catalyst samples to be tested were ‘fast’ aged at 1000 °C for 10 h using a muffle furnace with an atmosphere of 10% H2O and 2% O2. The cumulative tailpipe and total emissions for CO, HC (THC), NOx and N2O for the two catalyst systems tested by the WLTC cycle are shown in Figs. 6 and 7 . In general it can be observed that the majority of the CO and NOx emissions occur within the cold start and high speed regions and that THC emissions mainly occur within the initial 300 s of the test. It is evident that the TWC system utilizing the Rh-only UFC (Catalyst C) performs significantly better than the Pd/Rh UFC (Catalyst B) system in terms of the removal of CO and NOx under transient conditions and higher engine load and speed. Indeed the TWC system utilizing the Rh-only UFC showed improvements in CO and NOx conversion efficiency of up to 10–15%, but the emission of N2O is worse than Pd/Rh catalyst. For multi-brick exhaust systems, the close coupled (CC) and underfloor (UF) configuration utilized in this work is very common. Given that of the majority of HC emissions are during the cold start phase the contribution of the underfloor catalyst to HC removal is expected to be minimal. Therefore in consideration of the improved CO and NOx removal performance observed the Rh-only UFC represents a promising alternative to current Pd/Rh UFCs both in terms of performance and the potential to reduce PGM usage. 3.3 The formation of N2O and NH3 Fig.8 (a) and (b) show NO conversion and the N2O and NH3 formation for fresh and aged catalyst samples plotted against temperature. The temperature at which N2O and NH3 formation begins can be seen to vary with the different catalyst types and upon ageing. These temperatures in general correlate with the associated NOx light-off for each of the respective catalyst samples. J. L. Marc and co-workers [23] have previously reported a strong dependence between N2O formation and the temperature at which NO reduction occurs. N2O formation appears to be more favored at lower temperatures (200−400 °C) with the concentration of N2O observed to decrease at higher temperatures (>300 °C) [23,24] and most catalysts can be observed to stop generating N2O when catalyst temperatures exceed 450 °C [9]. Rhodium and palladium systems differ significantly terms of their propensity towards N2O and NH3 formation. A number of studies have been carried out in this area [23–25], with findings including that levels of N2O formation are greater for supported rhodium catalysts than platinum and palladium equivalents [25], that N2O is formed at lower temperatures for Rh and Pt catalysts (250−400 °C) compared to Pd catalysts (below 500 °C) [9] and that the observed levels of N2O formation are higher following catalyst deactivation owing to a decline in the N2O decomposition capability [24]. In our testing, under stoichiometric conditions, the fresh Rh-only catalyst was shown to form the highest total amount of N2O at the lowest temperature of all the catalyst samples tested. The integrated areas of N2O formation are shown in Table 5 and the fresh Rh-only catalyst sample was found to produce 2.6 and 3.5 times more N2O than the fresh Pd-only and Pd/Rh catalyst samples respectively. N2O formation was detected at approximately 200 °C with a maximum level of N2O formation of approximately 24% observed at 275 °C. This was followed by a steady decline to lower N2O levels. In comparison for the fresh Pd/Rh catalyst sample N2O formation was observed at 225 °C with a maximum level of N2O of approximately 32% at 270 °C. The amount of N2O from the fresh Pd-only catalyst sample reached a maximum of 28% at 287 °C. The Pd/Rh and Pd-only catalysts were observed to form N2O over a relatively narrow temperature window whereas the corresponding temperature window for the Rh-only catalyst sample was significantly wider. As shown in Table 5, for aged catalyst samples a general increase in the threshold temperatures for N2O formation was observed as well as wider temperature windows of formation. The maximum levels of N2O formation detected decreased in the order of Pd-only > Pd/Rh > Rh-only in comparison to the trend observed for fresh catalyst samples which decreased in the order of Rh-only > Pd/Rh > Pd-only. Fig. 9 (a) and (b) show the relationship between NOx conversion efficiency and N2O yield for the different catalyst samples tested. For the Pd-only and Pd-Rh fresh catalyst samples it can be observed that NOx conversion increases with N2O yield until a NOx conversion of approximately 83% is reached. However, for the Rh-only fresh catalyst, the yield of N2O reaches its highest point at a lower NOx conversion of approximately 58%. Upon ageing, the NOx conversion efficiency at which the yield of N2O reaches a maximum is decreased from 58% to 35% for the Rh catalyst sample and the maximum yield of N2O is decreased from 24% to 14%. However for the Pd-only and Pd-Rh catalyst samples, the NOx conversion efficiency at which the maximum yield of N2O was reached showed minimal change as compared to the corresponding fresh catalyst samples. The maximum N2O yield was reduced from 33% to 21% for Pd-Rh catalyst with the Pd-only catalyst sample showing minimal change. In consideration of the experimental conditions utilized for this work, it is expected that N2O is formed by the reaction of NO with CO and C3H6 according to Eqs. (1) and (2) (1) 2 N O + C O → N 2 O + C O 2 (2) C 3 H 6 + 14 N O + O 2 → 7 N 2 O + 3 C O 2 + 3 H 2 O N2O can also be formed by the reaction of NO with H2 according to Eq. (3). However there is no H2 in the reaction gas stream utilized for this work and although H2 can be generated by WGS and SR reactions, this is dependent upon temperature, gas composition and concentration [26]. (3) 2 N O + H 2 → N 2 O + H 2 O Differences in the selectivity of different metals towards N2O forming reactions may provide an explanation as to the different trends in N2O formation observed for fresh and aged catalysts. It is therefore possible that the reaction between CO and NOx represents the main N2O forming reaction for Rh-only catalyst systems, while for Pd-only catalysts the reaction between NO and C3H6 may be more significant. A number of mechanisms have been reported in the literature for N2O formation [23,24]. In addition a number of factors have been shown to impact N2O formation including A/F ratio, temperature, reaction gas composition and catalyst composition [11,27]. Matsuo Odaka and co-workers [24] have proposed that three way catalysis leads to N2O formation at low temperatures but decomposition of N2O at high temperatures and that the decomposition of N2O over a TWC differs according to catalyst ageing. It was suggested in their work that the decrease in N2O decomposition after ageing was due to changes in the OSC component of the TWC. J. L. Marc and co-workers [23] propose that the nature of the reaction of N2O with CO and C3H6 could explain the lack of N2O observed at higher temperatures (>450 °C), even in the presence of O2, NO and H2O. The lack of N2O at higher temperatures is explained by the absence of its formation depending upon the rate of NO dissociation and the specific temperature. The amount of NH3 formation observed for the catalyst samples tested was less than N2O. This was especially the case for the Rh-only catalyst sample where NH3 was only detected at low temperatures (<300 °C). The Pd-only catalyst was found to lead to the formation of the highest levels of NH3 followed by the Pd/Rh catalyst sample. It has been shown in the literature that the behavior of a mixed metal catalyst in terms of NH3 and N2O formation can be explained in terms of contributions from the individual metals [25]. Fig. 10 (a) and (b) illustrate the relationship between NOx conversion efficiency and NH3 yield for the different catalyst samples tested. It can be observed that in general as the NOx conversion increases, the yield of NH3 increases until a NOx conversion of 100% is reached except in the case of the Rh-only catalyst sample. In addition it is observed that catalyst ageing did not significantly change the maximum yield of NH3. This is in agreement with a study carried out by P. Nevalainen and co-workers [11] regarding the formation of NH3 and N2O over a modern natural gas three-way catalyst designed for heavy-duty vehicle applications. However within a NOx conversion range of 30–90% the NH3 yield for the Pd-only catalyst sample was reduced compared to fresh whereas the same reduction was not observed for the Pd/Rh catalyst sample. In contrast to the Pd-only and Pd/Rh catalyst samples, the Rh-only catalyst only forms NH3 at low NOx conversions in the range of 0–40%, with a maximum NH3 yield of approximately 4–6%. It has been shown in the literature that Pd, Pd/Rh or Pt/Rh catalyst systems form more NH3 under rich conditions than Rh-only catalyst systems [25,28,29]. The function of Rh has been extensively studied since the introduction of three-way catalysis and is known to promote N-pairing of adsorbed NO molecules prior to the breakage of the NO bond [17], thus suppressing the formation of NH3. E Catherine Adams and co-workers [30] have proposed that the presence of Rh in a TWC is a potential reason for the high selectivity towards N2 observed during the course of NOx reduction for the samples that they tested. The results obtained from our study are consistent with this. NO and H2 are essential reaction gas components for the formation of NH3. Although there is no direct input of H2 in our synthetic gas reactor testing, H2 can be formed by steam reforming (SR) of HC and water gas shift (WGS) at sufficient temperatures according to Eqs. (4) and (5). (4) C 3 H 6 + H 2 O → 3 C O + 6 H 2 (5) C O + H 2 O → C O 2 + H 2 In a study into the emissions of NH3, N2O and H2 from a Pd-only TWC Isidro Mejía-Centeno and co-workers [31] suggested that the H2 required for NH3 formation is produced by SR and WGS reactions. SR is activated at approximately 250 °C (2250 ppm of C3H8 and 8% by vol. of H2O for SR reaction), whereas WGS starts at approximately 320 °C (5000 ppm of CO, 1700 ppm of H2 and 8% by vol. of H2O for WGS reaction). In addition the presence of CeO2, enhances the generation of H2 at temperatures of above 300 °C thus promoting the formation of NH3 [31,19]. As shown in Table 5 and Fig. 8, NH3 formation is detected within the temperature range of 180 °C∼258 °C for the fresh Rh-only catalyst sample. In comparison, it is observed that Pd-only and Pd/Rh fresh catalysts form NH3 over a significantly broader temperature range (200 °C∼ >450 °C). After ageing, NH3 formation temperature is observed to shift to higher temperatures, with temperature ranges of 225 °C∼340 °C, 270 °C∼ >450 °C and 290 °C∼>450 °C observed respectively for Rh-only, Pd/Rh and Pd-only catalyst samples. Based upon these observations it can be seen that a proportion of NH3 is formed in the temperature range of 200−300 °C where SR and WGS reactions may not be favored. According to work carried out by some research groups, in addition to the reaction of NO and H2 shown in Eq. (6) an alternative reaction pathway for the formation of ammonia is possible involving the hydrolysis of isocyanate groups at low temperatures in NO, CO and H2O mixtures [32,33]. The reaction pathway is summarized in Eqs. (7)–(10) and although a catalytically active site (*) is initially required subsequent elementary ammonia formation reactions can take place in both the gas phase and/or via reactions on the surface of the catalyst [26]. According to Almusaiteer and co-workers [34], *-NCO is formed through the reaction of adsorbed CO with dissociated N according to Eq.(11), where* represents the reduced site and includes Rh, Pd, Ru, and Pt. Solymosi and co-workers [35] have also suggested that the primary step in the formation of isocyanate is the dissociation of NO on reduced sites [35]. In comparison with Rh catalysts, Pd° atoms are more resistant to oxidation than Rh° atoms below light-off [34], therefore *-NCO is easier to form on Pd than Rh catalyst. (6) N O + 5 2 H 2 → N H 3 + H 2 O (7) *−NCO + H2O ↔ *−OH + HNCO (8) HNCO + H2O ↔ NH3 + CO2 (9) *−NCO + H2O ↔ S-NH2 + CO2 (10) *−NH2 + H2O ↔ *−OH + NH3 (11) * - N + * - C O → * - N C O + * In addition in our previously published work [36], the formation of NH3 at low temperatures was attributed to the presence of OH groups, with NO reacting with OH groups to form nitrates and release NH3.While NH3 was formed at higher temperatures via the reduction of NOx by H2. 4 Conclusions The catalytic function of Pd-only, Pd/Rh and Rh-only catalysts has been investigated. The results from both synthetic gas reactor system testing and vehicle evaluation show that the Rh-only catalyst demonstrates a better performance for CO and NOx removal as a downstream catalyst when compared with the Pd/Rh catalyst and that the presence of Pd is essential for the oxidation of hydrocarbons in a three-way catalyst system. As a result replacement of a Pd/Rh UFC with an Rh-only derivative can lead an improvement in performance as well as presenting a viable option for the reduction of total PGM usage within a catalyst aftertreatment system. Rhodium and palladium differ significantly in terms of their activity towards N2O and NH3 formation. The behavior of a Pd/Rh catalyst in terms of NH3 and N2O formation can result from the contributions of the individual metals. The temperature at which N2O and NH3 begins to form can be correlated with the associated NOx light off temperature and has been shown to vary according to the different types of catalyst tested. The Rh-only catalyst has been shown to lead to the formation of the highest amount of N2O and the Pd-only catalyst forms the most NH3. coredata.dc:description: With the increase in worldwide automobile usage and the tightening of associated emissions legislation, the total demand of PGMs for use in automotive emission control catalysts is growing. Reducing the amount of required PGM in automotive catalysts as well as maintaining or improving the associated catalytic performance is an area of significant focus. This work presents a comparative study of the catalytic activity of Pd-only, Pd/Rh and Rh-only catalyst systems with respect to CO, HC and NOx conversion. The Rh-only catalyst has been shown to have the potential to improve CO and NOx conversions when functioning as a downstream catalyst compared with a Pd/Rh catalyst as well as reducing the usage of precious metals. In addition the formation of the three way catalysis by-products N2O and NH3 in different catalyst systems was investigated. The temperature of N2O and NH3 formation was shown to correlate with NOx light off temperatures and to vary depending upon the catalyst system employed and ageing conditions. The Rh-only catalyst was shown to generate the highest amount of N2O and the Pd-only catalyst the highest amount of NH3.
coredata.dc:title: A comparative study of Rh-only, Pd-only and Pd/Rh catalysts

dcterms:subject.$: Reducing the usage of precious metals
